12.0: A woman who dies while sitting on the birthing stool on Shabbos, we bring a knife to tear open her abdomen and remove the fetus

19.24: Whereas there, [it fits with what is said] "Praise, servants of Hashem" - and not [ie, are no longer] servants of Pa'aroh; here, "Praise, servants of Hashem" - and not [ie, only those who are no longer] the servants of Achashveirosh
19.25: [However] we are still servants of Achashveirosh
19.27: 'Its reading [of the Megillah] is its Hallel', isn't it recorded [in the B'raisa]
19.20: Before [the nation of] Israel entered the Land [of Israel], all other lands were appropriate to sing. After they entered the Land [of Israel], other lands were not appropriate to sing.
19.22: Its reading [of the Megillah] is its Hallel
19.28: 'After they entered the Land [of Israel], other lands were not appropriate to sing.'
19.29: Once they were exiled, [all other lands] were now appropriate as originally [before the nation of Israel entered the Land of Israel].
19.1: of the Chag [Sukkot] are separate in their sacrifices; [those] of Pesach are not separate in their sacrfices
19.2: Shabbat, which has unique sacrifices, [Hallel] should be said
19.5: It is not sanctified with [a prohibition against] doing work, as it is written
19.4: Rosh Chodesh, which is called a 'Moed', it should be said
19.7: Rosh Hashanah and Yom Hakippurim, which are called 'Moed', and are sanctified with [a prohibtion against] doing work, [Hallel] should be said?
19.6: "The song shall be for you as [on] the night of the sanctification of the holiday." That [day] which is sanctified as a holiday requires song; that [day] which is not sanctified as a holiday does not require song.
19.9: Master of the World, why does [the nation of] Israel not sing before you on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Hakippurim?
19.8: [It is not said] because of [the statement of] R' Abahu, as R' Abahu said, The ministering angels said before Hakadosh Baruch Hu,
19.11: Is it possible that the King sits on the Throne of Judgment, and the books of the live and the books of the dead are open before Him, and [the nation of] Israel sings before Me?
19.12: But [what about] Chanukah, that is not thus [called a Moed] and not thus [sanctified with a prohibition against doing work], and [yet, Hallel] is said?
19.14: Purim, [when] there is a miracle, it should be said?
19.16: Because we do not sing on a miracle [that occurred] in the diaspora
19.19: As it was recorded [according to the B'raisa]
19.18: But there is the exodus from Egypt, which [occurred] in the diaspora, and we say Hallel?

18.48: And in the diaspora, twenty- one days
18.49: The nine days of the Chag [Sukkot], the eight days of Chanukah, and the two [first] holy days of Pesach and the two holy days of Atzeret [Shavuot]
18.46: [On] eighteen days [of the year] and individual completes the Hallel
18.47: The eight days of the Chag [Sukkot], the eight days of Chanukah, and the first day of Pesach and the first day of Atzeret [Shavuot]
18.44: Since on these [days] an individual completes the Hallel
18.45: As R' Yohanan says in the name of R' Simeon ben Yehotzadak
18.42: Twelve days of the year the Chalil is played
18.43: Why are these [days] different [that the Chalil is played on them]?
18.50: Why is the Chag [Sukkot] different, that we say [Hallel] on each day, and why on Pesach do we not say [Hallel]?

31.0: This is when it is in public.

29.20: "This is the ritual (lit. Torah) for a leper..."
29.21: this is in reference to the law (lit. Torah) for one who speaks Lashon Harah
29.22: And Reish Lakish asks, "Where do we learn this?"
29.23: "If the serpent bites before it is charmed, the charmer has no advantage."
29.71: ...Death and life are in the power of the tongue; And they that indulge it shall eat the fruit thereof. (Proverbs 18:21)

2.24: — [Scripture says:] His offering,(Leviticus 1:3) i.e., but not his father's offering.
2.25: And he infers the rule concerning the commencement of the dedication of the animal from the rule governing its end.
2.26: Just as at the end of the dedication the heir does not lay on hands, thus also at the beginning he cannot effect a substitute.
2.20: An heir must lay on hands, an heir can effect a substitute.
2.22: An heir does not lay on hands, and an heir cannot effect a substitute.
2.23: What is the reason of R. Judah's view?
2.28: — [Scripture says redundantly:] And if he shall at all change — that included the heir.(Leviticus 27:10)
2.29: And we infer the rule concerning the end of the dedication from the rule governing the commencement of the dedication.
2.1: PERSONS OF UNKNOWN SEX AND HERMAPHRODITES ARE FIT TO VOW [ANOTHER'S WORTH], OR TO HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED, AND ARE FIT TO EVALUATE, BUT THEY ARE NOT FIT TO BE MADE THE SUBJECTS OF VALUATION, FOR THE SUBJECT OF VALUATION MAY BE ONLY A PERSON DEFINITELY EITHER MALE OR FEMALE.
2.0: [Mishnah]  ALL [PERSONS] ARE FIT TO EVALUATE OR TO BE MADE THE SUBJECTS OF VALUATION, ARE FIT TO VOW [ANOTHER'S WORTH] OR HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED: — PRIESTS, LEVITES AND [ORDINARY] ISRAELITES, WOMEN AND SLAVES.
2.3: [Gemarah]  What does ALL [PERSONS] ARE FIT TO EVALUATE mean to include?
2.2: A DEAF-MUTE, AN IMBECILE, OR A MINOR ARE FIT TO HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED OR BE MADE THE SUBJECT OF VALUATION, BUT THEY ARE NOT FIT TO MAKE EITHER A VOW [OF ANOTHER'S WORTH] OR TO EVALUATE, BECAUSE THEY HAVE NO MIND.
2.5: What does [ALL7 ARE] FIT TO BE MADE THE SUBJECTS OF VALUATION mean to include? —
2.4: — It is meant to include one close to manhood who must be examined.
2.7: For one might have assumed that since Scripture says:
2.6: It is meant to include a person disfigured, or one afflicted with boils.
2.8: A vow according to thy valuation, that only such persons as are fit to be made the subjects of a vow [as regards their worth], are fit to be made subjects of a valuation, and that persons who are unfit to be made subjects of a vow [as regards their worth], are also unfit to be made subjects of a valuation, hence Scripture informs us: of persons. i.e.,
2.11: [The phrase ALL] is needed only for [the clause]
2.10: What does [ALL PERSONS] ARE FIT TO VOW mean to include? —
2.13: — What is to be included [in the phrase ALL] ARE FIT TO HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED? Is it to include persons of unknown sex or hermaphrodites — but they are expressly stated [in our Mishnah]! Again is it to include a deaf-mute, an imbecile and a minor — they too are expressly stated! And if it is to include a person below the age of one month — that too is expressly mentioned! And again if it is to include an idolater — he too is expressly mentioned!
2.12: ‘are fit to have their worth vowed’
2.15: What does ‘All persons are obliged to lay on hands’ mean to include?
2.14: — In reality it is meant to include a person below the age of one month; and the Mishnah states it [by implication] and later on expressly mentions it.
2.17: What does ‘All persons can effect a substitute’ mean to include? —
2.16: — It is meant to include the heir, and this against the view of R. Judah.
2.18: That, too, means to include the heir, in contrast to the view of R. Judah.
2.31: But what do the Rabbis do with
2.30: Just as at the beginning of the dedication the heir has power to effect a substitute, so at the end is he obliged to lay his hands on the animal's head.
2.35: or, indeed, if he should hold so
2.34: And R. Judah? — He does not hold that all who have a share in the ownership share the obligation of laying hands thereon;
2.33: ‘his offering’, but not the offering of an idolater; ‘his offering’, but not the offering of his neighbour; ‘his offering. i.e., to include all who have a share in the ownership of a sacrifice in the duty to lay on hands.

32.5: 'A generation parallels that of its leader.' And one says:
32.4: "This is the generation of them that seek him that seek thy face, O Jacob. Selah" (Psalms 24:16). R. Yehudah HaNasi and the Rabbis disagreed on how to interpret this verse. One says:
32.6: 'A leader parallels that of his generation'
